title: Tory rebels ready to take credit for new Brexit deal
text:
LONDON — If Boris Johnson does get a Brexit deal, some of his fiercest critics are lining up to take credit.

Oliver Letwin, one of 21 Conservative MPs stripped of the party whip for voting against the government last month, told POLITICO that the rebels had effectively forced the prime minister back to the negotiating table with Brussels by removing no-deal as an option.

Other members of the so-called rebel alliance are taking a similar line. David Gauke, a former Cabinet minister and outspoken critic of the Downing Street operation, said the rebellion had prompted “more engagement” with Brussels. Alistair Burt, another ex-minister who spent the Conservative conference last week hammering the Johnson administration, said it “would be great” to think the insurgency was one of the most successful in recent Conservative history.

Their joy comes despite the EU appearing to reject the Johnson proposals on arrival — with some suggesting the prime minister has put forward an unrealistic plan as a ploy that will allow him to blame the EU if negotiations break down — and despite Johnson sticking to his line that the U.K. is leaving on October 31.

"If a reasonable deal is reached, I will support it." — David Gauke, former Cabinet minister

The rebel MPs were instrumental in successfully pushing for parliament to back the Benn Act, which forces the prime minister to request a Brexit delay if he can't strike a deal with the EU by October 19 rather than take the U.K. out of the EU with no deal.

They were collectively crowned the most influential Londoners of 2019 by the Evening Standard newspaper at an awards ceremony on Thursday night (Tory chairman James Cleverly, who was at the event, made rude gestures when they picked up the gong).

Johnson has repeatedly argued that the Benn Act — the "Surrender Act," as he likes to call it — has made negotiations harder.

“It has had the effect with our European friends of making them think maybe parliament can block this thing — maybe they will be forced to extend,” he told Sky News in late September. “If you are in a negotiation that obviously makes it more difficult.”

Peace (for a time)

Despite all the bad blood in the Tory ranks, things changed when Johnson sent his Brexit proposals to Brussels on Wednesday afternoon — resulting in an outbreak of unity between Downing Street and many of the Tory MPs who have been condemning his premiership.

In a statement Thursday, Burt and Gauke welcomed the plan to impose a customs border in Ireland and a regulatory border down the Irish Sea, all underpinned by a vote of consent from the Northern Irish Assembly, while other Tory rebels — Steve Brine, Stephen Hammond and Greg Clark — all offered warm words for the plan.

Burt told POLITICO he could vote for a deal along the lines of the proposals from Downing Street and insisted he believed Johnson was negotiating in good faith.

“All I ever wanted to do was make sure we left with a deal and that nobody in the Conservative Party was under any illusion that leaving without a deal was a good thing,” he said. “If what we have done has helped propel that then I’m very pleased because that is what we are determined to do.”

Letwin, who helped draw up the Benn Act, also said he could vote for a deal like the one put forward by Johnson if Brussels approves it.

Asked whether the efforts of the rebels had paid off by forcing the prime minister back to the negotiating table, Letwin simply said: “Yes.”

Gauke said: “If a reasonable deal is reached, I will support it. Without the rebellion of 3rd September I think we would have left without a deal on 31st October so I am pleased there’s now more engagement. But we’ve a lot to get through in very little time.”

He said the fight against no-deal could be far from over.

“I would want to support a deal if at all possible,” he said. “It is helpful that the government has now set out its proposals but that is what they are — proposals. There’s much work to be done to get a deal.”

Downing Street pushed back against the idea that the rebels had forced the prime minister to the negotiating table.

“The PM has been clear since day one he would seek a new deal,” an official said. “The PM is pleased the majority of his party trusted he would do just that. We want all MPs to support the proposals.”

Route back in

If the rebels do support the proposals, it could be a way for them to re-take the Tory whip.

Party chairman Cleverly told a fringe event at the Conservative Party’s annual conference on Tuesday that “there should always be a path to a redemption.” He added: “I would love to see a route back but I think there does have to be a demonstration of loyalty.”

Some, including Burt, have already said they won't stand again at the next election, and on Friday Rory Stewart said he would instead stand as an independent to become mayor of London. Another rebel, Sam Gyimah, has joined the Liberal Democrats.

But the likes of Gauke, Brine and Clark have left open whether they intend to run at the next election. They will not be allowed to stand as a Tory MP without going through an appeals process.

Another one of the 21 rebels said they wouldn't back a deal just to get back into the party's good graces: “My support for a good deal won’t be conditional on getting the whip back. If it’s right for the country it’s right for the country regardless of my personal status.”

Other members of the 21 are still refusing to play ball. Grieve said he would vote against any deal that came without a call for a second referendum.

“I would vote for a confirmatory referendum,” he said. “I’m perfectly happy to see such a deal put to the public but only with a confirmatory referendum with the alternative option of remaining.”

One former Cabinet minister, who spoke to POLITICO on condition of anonymity, was hopeful that a deal would be the glue to bring all sides together, even the rebels.

“Everyone agrees that if [Johnson] does actually get a deal and get that deal through parliament then he becomes an all-purpose national hero — he has done something nobody else could manage,” the minister said. “And a part of that would be the reuniting of the Conservative Party.”
description: Boris Johnson says they’ve made things harder but rebels argue they forced PM’s hand.
